title: Implement DALL-E 3 API integration for image generation
description: Call DALL-E 3 API with PM summary to generate branded social media images. Configure size (1080x1080 for posts, 1080x1920 for stories), quality (hd), style. Handle generation and download.
notes:
DALL-E 3 Image Generation for LinkedIn

Goal: Create professional, eye-catching images that complement technical LinkedIn posts and attract executive attention.

Image Specifications:
- Size: 1200x627 (LinkedIn recommended) or 1080x1080 (square)
- Quality: hd (DALL-E 3 parameter)
- Style: vivid (more engaging) or natural (more professional)
- Format: PNG (returned by DALL-E 3)

Visual Style Guidelines:
- Clean, modern, professional aesthetic
- Tech-forward but not too abstract
- Data visualization when metrics are available
- Minimal text overlays (LinkedIn prefers text in post, not image)
- Brand colors if repo has established palette
- Avoid cluttered designs

DALL-E 3 Prompt Structure:

For PERFORMANCE commits:
A clean, modern data visualization showing performance improvement metrics. Professional business aesthetic with gradients of blue and green. Graph showing before and after comparison. Tech startup vibe, minimal and sleek. No text overlays.

For SECURITY commits:
A professional illustration of secure infrastructure. Lock icon, shield, or encryption visualization. Corporate tech aesthetic with blues and grays. Modern, trustworthy design. Abstract but clearly about security.

For FEATURE commits:
A modern illustration showing new capability or feature. Professional SaaS product aesthetic. Clean lines, gradient backgrounds. Tech-forward but accessible. Represents innovation and growth.

For BUG FIX commits:
A professional visualization of problem-solving or system reliability. Checkmarks, stable systems, or uptime indicators. Reassuring colors like green and blue. Corporate professional style.

Prompt Template:
---
Create a professional LinkedIn post image for a software engineering announcement about {commit_type}. 

Theme: {theme_based_on_commit}
Style: Modern tech company aesthetic, clean and minimal
Colors: {brand_colors or professional_blue_green_gradient}
Mood: {innovative/reliable/secure/efficient}
Elements: {relevant_icons_or_visualizations}

Requirements:
- Professional business context
- No text overlays or labels
- 16:9 aspect ratio
- Suitable for executives and investors
- Tech-forward but not overly technical
---

Image Processing:
1. Call DALL-E 3 API with generated prompt
2. Receive image URL from OpenAI
3. Download image from URL (valid for 1 hour)
4. Upload to S3 for permanent storage
5. Return S3 URL for LinkedIn posting

Error Handling:
- Content policy violations: Fall back to generic tech imagery
- API failures: Retry with exponential backoff
- Download failures: Retry download up to 3 times
- Invalid images: Log and use fallback placeholder

Go Implementation:
- Use openai-go SDK (sashabaranov/go-openai)
- HTTP client for image download
- AWS SDK for S3 upload
- Image validation before upload

Configuration:
- OPENAI_API_KEY
- DALLE_IMAGE_SIZE (1024x1024 or 1792x1024)
- DALLE_QUALITY (hd or standard)
- DALLE_STYLE (vivid or natural)
- S3_BUCKET for image storage

Cost Optimization:
- DALL-E 3 HD: 0.080 per image (1024x1024)
- DALL-E 3 Standard: 0.040 per image
- Start with Standard quality for MVT
- Upgrade to HD if quality matters
- Cache generated images (never regenerate same commit)

Alternative Approach (Post-MVT):
Instead of pure DALL-E generation, consider:
1. Template-based images (faster, cheaper, more consistent)
2. Use image manipulation library (Go imaging packages)
3. Overlay text, metrics, logos on template backgrounds
4. Only use DALL-E for backgrounds or abstract visuals
5. This gives more control over branding and layout

For now, use pure DALL-E 3 for simplicity.

title: Configure AWS credentials in GitHub Secrets
description: Required: Add AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID_DEV, AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY_DEV, AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID_PROD, AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY_PROD to GitHub repo secrets. Manual configuration step.
notes:
DECISION POINT: Repository Secrets vs Environment Secrets

## GitHub Secrets Options

### Option A: Repository Secrets (What I initially suggested)
- Available to all workflows
- No environment protection rules
- Simpler setup
- Good for: Small projects, single environment

### Option B: Environment Secrets (BETTER for this use case)
- Separate secrets per environment (dev, prod)
- Can add protection rules (require approvals, restrict branches)
- More organized and secure
- Best practice for multi-environment deployments

## RECOMMENDATION: Use Environment Secrets

### Why Environment Secrets Are Better:

1. **Security**: Can require manual approval before prod deployment
2. **Organization**: Clearly separated dev vs prod credentials
3. **Protection**: Can restrict prod to only main branch
4. **Visibility**: Easy to see which env uses which secrets
5. **Industry Standard**: How most CI/CD pipelines are structured

### Setup Structure:

Create two environments:
- **dev** environment with dev AWS credentials
- **prod** environment with prod AWS credentials

### Workflow Integration:



Note: With environments, you use the SAME secret names but they're scoped to the environment.

### Protection Rules You Can Add:

For **prod** environment:
- ‚úÖ Required reviewers (manual approval before deploy)
- ‚úÖ Wait timer (e.g., 5 minute delay)
- ‚úÖ Deployment branches: Only 'main' can deploy

For **dev** environment:
- No restrictions (auto-deploy on PR)

UPDATING PLAN TO USE ENVIRONMENT SECRETS.

title: Research OpenAI Sora API integration
description: Research current Sora API status, endpoints, authentication, video generation parameters, pricing, limits. CRITICAL: Sora may still be in limited beta - verify API access and document integration approach.
notes:
## SORA API RESEARCH FINDINGS (November 2025)

### ‚úÖ API AVAILABILITY: YES (Limited)

**Current Status:**
- Sora 2 API is NOW AVAILABLE through OpenAI platform
- Official documentation at: https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/video-generation
- API Reference: https://platform.openai.com/docs/api-reference/videos
- Model page: https://platform.openai.com/docs/models/sora-2-pro

**Access Methods:**
1. **Direct OpenAI API** (requires API key)
2. **Azure OpenAI** (enterprise, preview access)

### üîë API ENDPOINTS

Based on Azure documentation (OpenAI uses similar structure):

**1. Create Video Job**
POST /v1/videos
- Async job creation
- Returns job_id for polling

**2. Check Job Status**
GET /v1/video/generations/jobs/{job_id}
- Poll every 5 seconds
- Status: pending, processing, succeeded, failed, cancelled

**3. Download Video**
GET /v1/video/generations/{generation_id}/content/video
- Returns MP4 binary content

### üìù REQUEST PARAMETERS

Required:
- model: 'sora-2' or 'sora-2-pro'
- prompt: Text description (up to detailed narratives)

Optional:
- width / height: Resolution (480p, 720p, 1080p, 1920p)
- n_seconds: Duration (up to 20 seconds max)
- n_variants: Number of videos to generate
- size: Aspect ratio presets

Advanced (image/video inpainting):
- inpaint_items: Array with file_name, frame_index, crop_bounds

### üí∞ PRICING (Estimated)

**Official OpenAI Pricing: NOT YET PUBLISHED**

**Estimated based on third-party sources:**
- ~$0.10 - $0.50 per second of video
- Varies by resolution (720p cheaper, 1080p more expensive)
- Average estimate: $0.40 per 15-second clip = $2.67/video

**For our use case (short commits):**
- 10-second videos @ $0.20/sec = $2.00/video
- 100 videos/month = $200/month (Sora costs alone)

**Subscription Tiers (ChatGPT):**
- ChatGPT Plus: $20/mo (1,000 credits, ~5s 720p videos)
- ChatGPT Pro: $200/mo (10,000 credits, watermark-free, priority)

### ‚öôÔ∏è TECHNICAL CONSTRAINTS

**Video Specs:**
- Max duration: 20 seconds
- Formats: MP4 output
- Resolutions: 480p, 720p, 1080p, 1920p
- Audio: Synchronized audio generation included in Sora 2

**Rate Limits:**
- Not documented yet (TBD when we get API access)
- Expect similar to other OpenAI APIs (RPM/RPD limits by tier)

**Generation Time:**
- UNKNOWN - likely 30 seconds to several minutes per video
- CRITICAL: This means we NEED async processing (Lambda 15min timeout may work)

**Content Filtering:**
- Automatic content moderation
- Harmful prompts rejected with no video generated

### üö® PROJECT BLOCKERS RESOLVED

‚úÖ **API EXISTS**: Sora 2 API is available (not vaporware)
‚úÖ **DOCUMENTATION**: Official OpenAI docs published
‚úÖ **AUTHENTICATION**: Standard OpenAI API key
‚úÖ **PROGRAMMATIC ACCESS**: REST API with async job pattern

### ‚ö†Ô∏è REMAINING UNKNOWNS

‚ùì **API Access**: Do we need special approval or just an API key?
‚ùì **Exact Pricing**: Official per-second cost from OpenAI
‚ùì **Rate Limits**: Requests per minute/day
‚ùì **Generation Time**: How long does a 10-second video take?
‚ùì **Geographic Restrictions**: US/Canada only or global?

### üìã NEXT STEPS

1. **Get API Access**: Sign up at platform.openai.com, get API key
2. **Test Generation**: Create simple test video to measure:
   - Generation time (affects Lambda timeout decision)
   - Actual cost (affects pricing model)
   - Video quality for commit diffs
3. **Prompt Engineering**: Test how well commit messages translate to videos
4. **Rate Limit Testing**: Determine concurrent request limits

### üéØ RECOMMENDATION: PROCEED WITH PROJECT

**Verdict: ‚úÖ PROJECT IS VIABLE**

The Sora API is real, available, and well-documented. While pricing is TBD, estimated costs ($2-3/video) are acceptable for a SaaS model with monthly fees.

**Architecture Decision:**
- Use async processing (SQS + Lambda or ECS Fargate)
- Start with Sora 2 (standard), upgrade to Pro if quality matters
- Cache generated videos in S3 (don't regenerate)
- Implement rate limiting to control costs

**Fallback if too expensive:**
- DALL-E 3 image sequences + ffmpeg
- RunwayML Gen-2
- Pika Labs

title: Design GPT-4 prompt system for PM-level commit summaries
description: Create prompt templates to transform technical git commits into product manager-style summaries. Focus on user benefits, non-technical language, professional tone. Include variables for repo context, commit type, customization.
notes:
GPT-4 Prompt Engineering for LinkedIn

Goal: Transform technical git commits into compelling LinkedIn posts that help OSS projects attract funding and executive attention.

Target Audience:
- CTOs, VPs of Engineering, Technical Directors
- Investors (VCs, Angels) looking for innovative projects
- Corporate development and DevRel teams
- Technical decision-makers with budget authority

Prompt Structure:

SYSTEM PROMPT:
You are a technical product marketing expert who translates software engineering work into business value for executive audiences. Transform git commits into engaging LinkedIn posts that highlight business impact, technical innovation, and open source value.

USER PROMPT TEMPLATE:
---
Repository: {repo_name}
Project Description: {repo_description}
Commit Message: {commit_message}
Code Changes Summary: {diff_summary}
Commit Author: {author_name}

Create a LinkedIn post that:
1. Starts with an attention-grabbing hook (emoji + benefit statement)
2. Explains the business problem being solved
3. Describes the technical solution in accessible terms
4. Highlights measurable impact (performance, cost, reliability, security)
5. Emphasizes open source benefits (transparency, no vendor lock-in, community)
6. Ends with relevant hashtags (3-5 tags)
7. Length: 500-1000 characters
8. Tone: Professional but conversational, technical but accessible
9. Focus on WHY this matters to businesses and users, not just WHAT changed
---

Output Requirements:
- No markdown formatting (LinkedIn strips it)
- Use emojis sparingly (1-2 max, professional context only)
- Break into short paragraphs (2-3 lines each)
- Include metrics when available (percentages, time saved, cost reduction)
- Avoid jargon, explain technical terms
- Call to action: encourage following the project, contributing, or sponsoring

Example Transformations:

INPUT: fix: prevent memory leak in cache invalidation
OUTPUT:
üîß Infrastructure Reliability Improvement

Fixed a critical memory leak that could cause service degradation over time. Our caching layer now properly releases memory when invalidating old entries.

Impact: Servers can run for weeks without restarts, reducing operational overhead and improving uptime for production deployments.

This is why open source infrastructure matters - when issues are found, they are fixed transparently and everyone benefits.

#OpenSource #SRE #Infrastructure #DevOps

---

INPUT: feat: add OAuth2 authentication support
OUTPUT:
üîê Enterprise-Ready Authentication

Just shipped OAuth2 support, making it easier for companies to integrate our tool into their existing security infrastructure.

Why it matters: IT teams can now use single sign-on, enforce MFA policies, and manage access centrally - critical requirements for enterprise adoption.

This upgrade opens doors for larger organizations who were blocked by authentication requirements. Ready to deploy in your corporate environment.

#EnterpriseIT #Authentication #Security #OpenSource

---

Prompt Variations by Commit Type:

FIX commits: Focus on reliability, stability, user experience
FEAT commits: Focus on new capabilities, business opportunities, competitive advantage
PERF commits: Focus on cost savings, scalability, efficiency gains
REFACTOR commits: Focus on maintainability, technical debt reduction, long-term value
DOCS commits: Focus on accessibility, adoption, community growth
TEST commits: Focus on quality, confidence, production readiness
SECURITY commits: Focus on risk reduction, compliance, trust

Special Instructions:
- If commit mentions metrics (speed, memory, cost), emphasize those numbers
- If commit fixes a CVE or security issue, highlight the severity and fix
- If commit enables new use cases, describe who benefits
- Always connect technical changes to business outcomes
- For B2B projects, emphasize enterprise readiness and support

title: Implement YouTube Shorts upload integration
description: Integrate LinkedIn API v2 for posting images with professional text captions. Use LinkedIn Share API for organization pages. OAuth 2.0 for authentication (3-legged flow). Permissions needed: w_member_social, w_organization_social. Support both personal profiles and company pages.
notes:
LinkedIn API Integration Details

API Endpoints:
- Share API: POST /v2/ugcPosts
- Image Upload: POST /v2/assets?action=registerUpload
- Organization Posts: POST /v2/shares

Authentication:
- OAuth 2.0 three-legged flow
- Required permissions: r_liteprofile, w_member_social, w_organization_social
- Store access tokens in AWS Secrets Manager
- Implement token refresh logic

Image Upload Process:
1. Register upload with LinkedIn API
2. Receive upload URL from LinkedIn
3. Upload image binary to provided URL
4. Get asset URN in response
5. Reference asset URN in post creation

Content Specifications:
- Max text length: 3,000 characters
- Optimal length: 500-1,000 chars for engagement
- Image size: 1200x627 recommended or 1080x1080
- Format: Professional tone, business impact focused
- Hashtags: 3-5 relevant tags

Post Structure:
- author: LinkedIn person or org URN
- lifecycleState: PUBLISHED
- shareCommentary: text content
- shareMediaCategory: IMAGE
- media array: contains uploaded image asset URN
- visibility: PUBLIC

Go Implementation:
- Use golang.org/x/oauth2 for OAuth flow
- HTTP client for LinkedIn API calls
- JSON marshaling for request/response
- Error handling for rate limits and auth failures

Rate Limits:
- 100 posts per day per person
- Check X-RateLimit headers in responses
- Implement backoff for 429 responses

Configuration Required:
- LINKEDIN_CLIENT_ID from app registration
- LINKEDIN_CLIENT_SECRET from app registration  
- LINKEDIN_REDIRECT_URI for OAuth callback
- LINKEDIN_ORG_ID for company page posting

Testing Approach:
1. Register LinkedIn developer app
2. Test OAuth flow with personal account
3. Verify post appears on LinkedIn feed
4. Test image upload and rendering
5. Test company page posting if org available

title: Research FxPlug4 SDK architecture and requirements
description: Document FxPlug4 API structure, required protocols, plugin lifecycle, parameter system, and rendering pipeline. Create architecture decision document.
notes:
FXPLUG4 ARCHITECTURE RESEARCH - COMPLETE

## DEVELOPMENT REQUIREMENTS
- Xcode 15+ required
- macOS 11.0+ minimum
- Swift 5+ or Objective-C
- FxPlug SDK: https://developer.apple.com/download/more/?=FXPlug
- Final Cut Pro 10.4.4+ for FxPlug 4
- Motion app required for FCP template wrapper

## SDK INSTALLATION (Sparse SDK)
Build Settings:
- Additional SDKs: /Library/Developer/SDKs/FxPlug.sdk
- Framework Search Paths: /Library/Frameworks $(inherited)

## PLUGIN ARCHITECTURE
Plugin Types: FxFilter (our zoom), FxGenerator, FxTransition
Required Protocol: FxPlugProtocol
Key Methods: plugInGroups(), properties(), versionCheck()

Rendering: Metal (recommended), OpenGL (deprecated), Core Image, Core Graphics

## CRITICAL INSIGHT
FxPlug plugins REQUIRE Motion template wrapper to work in Final Cut Pro!
Workflow: Build plugin ‚Üí Install ‚Üí Open Motion ‚Üí Create "Final Cut Effect" ‚Üí Publish params ‚Üí Save .moti

## METAL RENDERING
- OpenGL deprecated, use Metal for GPU acceleration
- Debug: Disable Metal API Validation in Xcode (SIGABRT bug)
- Real example: Gyroflow Toolbox (github.com/latenitefilms/GyroflowToolbox)

## PARAMETER SYSTEM
Types: Sliders, point pickers, checkboxes, menus, colors
Publishing: Expose in Motion (selective - don't overwhelm users)
Rigging: Multiple params ‚Üí single control
Limitation: ParameterSubGroup names cannot change dynamically

## BUNDLE STRUCTURE
Install location: /Library/Plug-Ins/FxPlug/
Verify: pluginkit -m -p FxPlug
Crash logs: ~/Library/Logs/DiagnosticReports
Auto-restart after crash, 3 crashes in 30s = disabled

## ZOOM EFFECT DESIGN
Transform: Scale matrix + translation for center point
Parameters needed:
- Zoom Amount: 1.0-5.0x
- Center Point: (X,Y) normalized
- Easing: Linear, ease-in, ease-out, bezier
- Duration: Auto or manual keyframes

Metal shader: Scale texture coords around center, high-quality sampling (Lanczos/bicubic)

## REFERENCE CODE
1. FxBrightness - Only official Swift example (in SDK)
2. Gyroflow Toolbox - Production Metal implementation (open source)
3. FxKit - MIT licensed Swift framework

## LANGUAGE CHOICE
Swift 5+ recommended (modern, FxBrightness template available)
Objective-C has more docs but verbose

## COMMON PITFALLS
- Red overlay bug: Always provide valid textures
- Thread safety: No AppKit on background threads
- Undo: Implement in start/endAction: blocks
- Metal Validation: Must disable for debugging

## PERFORMANCE TARGETS
4K real-time: 30fps minimum
GPU usage: <70%
Memory: <500MB

## NEXT STEPS
Use FxBrightness as template
Implement Metal zoom shader
Add parameter system
Create Motion wrapper
Test in FCP
